com.datamelt.rules.engine

Class BusinessRulesEngine

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.datamelt.rules.engine.BusinessRulesEngine

  • public class BusinessRulesEngine
extends java.lang.Object
    engine for executing business rules.

    rules are defined in xml files. additionally a replacements (properties) file might be specified, where variable names and replacement values for them are specified. this way values, that are used repeatedly in an xml file might be defined once and used multiple times.

    the engine executes rules which are defined in the form of groups and subgroups. rules in a subgroup belong together and are chained using either 'and' or 'or'. additionally subgroups may be chained together 'and' or 'or'.

    the engine accepts multiple xml rule files as input. this way the rules may be divided into multiple files. each file must contain a complete group of rules; groups can not be split over multiple files.

    rule xml files can also be put into a zip archive. the program will process the zip file and read all rule xml files from it.

    The Business Rules Maintenance Tool, a web application to orchestrate the business logic into projects, rulesgroups, rules and actions generates a zip file containing all logic which can then be used together with the rule engine. The zip file contains the mentioned xml files, so using the web application you will not have to write them by hand. In this case, also any available reference fields - a definition of which fields are available from the data record - are parsed from the zip file.

    the rules are executed against the data using a certain check or condition. these are defined in classes implementing the GenericCheck interface.

    rules defined in the xml file(s), or zip file are instantiated using java reflection. usually the return value of a method is compared to an expected value. or two object are compared against each other. or the return value is compared against a fix condition such as 'not null'.

    the getRuleDefinition method returns a simple readable representation and overview of the rule logic.

    before running the ruleengine it needs data to run the rules against. use one of the various run methods to pass objects to the engine. the object could be any object but needs to correspond to the object class defined in the rules project (file). The method to be used is also defined in the project. Using the class and the method, the data is retrieved from the object and passed to the ruleengine.

    please read the available documentation.

    Author:
    uwe geercken - uwe.geercken@web.de - Copyright 2008-2019

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      BusinessRulesEngine(java.io.File[] rulesFiles)
      engine can be instantiated by passing an array of files the files will be parsed and all rules from all files will be collected.
      BusinessRulesEngine(java.io.File[] rulesFiles, java.lang.String propertiesFile)
      engine can be instantiated by passing an array of files the files will be parsed and all rules from all files will be collected the properties file is an external file that is used to define several parameters used by the engine Rulegroups are prioritized to execute those groups first, that other groups depend on.

      engine can be instantiated by passing the filename, the file will be parsed and all rules will be collected.

      engine can be instantiated by passing a zip file containing xml rule files and specifying an array of the names of the rule files to process.

    • Constructor Detail

      • BusinessRulesEngine

        public BusinessRulesEngine(java.lang.String rulesFilename)
                    throws java.lang.Exception
        engine can be instantiated by passing the filename, the file will be parsed and all rules will be collected. alternatively the path and name of a folder, which contains the rule files, can be used. Rulegroups are prioritized to execute those groups first, that other groups depend on.
        Parameters:
        rulesFilename - path and name of the xml rule file or of the folder containing the files
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - exception when the file(s) could not be located or parsed

                           java.lang.String propertiesFile)
                    throws java.lang.Exception
        engine can be instantiated by passing the filename the file will be parsed and all rules will be collected the properties file is an external file that is used to define several parameters used by the engine Rulegroups are prioritized to execute those groups first, that other groups depend on.
        Parameters:
        rulesFilename - the path and name of the XML rule file
        propertiesFile - the path and name of the properties file
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - exception when the file were not found or could not be processed

      • BusinessRulesEngine

        public BusinessRulesEngine(java.util.zip.ZipFile zipFile,
                           java.lang.String[] ruleFiles)
                    throws java.lang.Exception
        engine can be instantiated by passing a zip file containing xml rule files and specifying an array of the names of the rule files to process. all other rule files will be ignored. the files will be parsed and all rules from all relevant files will be collected Rulegroups are prioritized to execute those groups first, that other groups depend on.
        Parameters:
        zipFile - path and name of the zip file
        ruleFiles - array containing the rulefile names to process
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - exception when the file could not be located or parsed

      • run

        public void run(java.lang.String objectLabel,
                java.lang.Object object)
         throws java.lang.Exception
        method runs the rules for all groups and subgroups against the object with the given label
        Parameters:
        objectLabel - the label to use for the object
        object - the actual object to use
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - exception running the rule against the object

      • run

        public void run(java.lang.String rulegroupName,
                java.lang.String objectLabel,
                java.lang.Object object)
         throws java.lang.Exception
        method runs the rules for a given rule group by specifying the group id. against the object with the given label. Only the given rulegroup will be executed. Note that if the given rulegroup depends on another group result (passed/failed), then that rulegroup shall be execute first. The compare of the rulegroup name is not case sensitive.
        Parameters:
        rulegroupName - the name of the rulegroup to run
        objectLabel - the label to use for the object
        object - the actual object to use
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - exception running the rule against the object

      • run

        public void run(java.lang.String[] rulegroupNames,
                java.lang.String objectLabel,
                java.lang.Object object)
         throws java.lang.Exception
        method runs the rules for a given array of rule groups by specifying the group names. against the object with the given label. The rulegroups will be executed in the order that they appear in the project zip file, but in any case those groups other groups depend on are executed first. Only the given rulegroup will be executed. Note that if the given rulegroup depends on another group result (passed/failed), then that rulegroup shall be execute first. The compare of the rulegroup name is not case sensitive.
        Parameters:
        rulegroupNames - array of names of the rulegroups to run
        objectLabel - the label to use for the object
        object - the actual object to use
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - exception running the rule against the object

      • run

        public void run(RuleGroup group,
                java.lang.String objectLabel,
                java.lang.Object object)
         throws java.lang.Exception
        method runs the rules for a given rule group against the object with the given label. if you run a single rule group and it is depending on another rule group make sure that the rule group it depends on is run first - a check on the result of the group it depends on (passed/failed) will be made in this method to determine if the rule group should run.
        Parameters:
        group - the rule group to run
        objectLabel - the label to use for the object
        object - the actual object to use
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - exception running the rule against the object

      • run

        public void run(java.util.Collection<java.lang.Object> objects)
         throws java.lang.Exception
        method runs the rules for all groups and subgroups for all objects of the collection. objectLabel is used to label the result of a rule in the output so that it can be identified.
        Parameters:
        objects - a collection of objects to run the rule against
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - exception running the rule against the object

        public boolean getRuleGroupFailed(java.lang.String groupId)

      • getRuleGroupsFailed

        public boolean getRuleGroupsFailed(java.lang.String[] groupIds)
        checks if any - at least one - of the groups in an array of rule group ids failed. a check of each group of the array is done, if it failed. if the group does not exist then the result for that group will be returned as false. you can evaluate if a group failed or not after the business rule engine was run.
        Parameters:
        groupIds - an array of group ids
        Returns:
        indicator if any of the groups failed

        Returns:
        if the number of passed groups is greater than the given value

      • getRuleGroupsStatus

        public boolean getRuleGroupsStatus(int mode)
        evaluates if the specified mode is true or false in regards to the number of rulegroups passed or failed. Modes are "at least one failed", "all failed", "Not all failed", "at least one passed", "all passed" and "not all passed". "at least one failed" means that the number of failed rulegroups is greater than zero "all failed" means that the number of passed rulegroups is equal to zero "not all failed" means that the number of failed rulegroups is smaller than the total number of rulegroups. also true if no rulegroup failed. "at least one passed" means that the number of passed rulegroups is greater than zero "all passed" means that the number of failed rulegroups is equal to zero "not all passed" means that the number of passed rulegroups is smaller than the total number of rulegroups. also true if no rulegroup passed. returns always true when the number of rulegroups is zero.
        Parameters:
        mode - the desired mode to compare to
        Returns:
        indicator if the mode is true or false

      • getRuleGroupsMinimumNumberFailed

        public boolean getRuleGroupsMinimumNumberFailed(int value)
        evaluates if the number of groups failed is equal or larger than the specified value
        Parameters:
        value - the minimum number of failed rulegroups
        Returns:
        if the number of failed rulegroups is equal or larger

      • getNumberOfGroupsSkipped

        public long getNumberOfGroupsSkipped()
        method returns the number of groups that were skipped. groups may be skipped when they depend on another group and the execution result (failed/passed) of that group is different than the expected result.
        Returns:
        number of skipped groups

      • getStatus

        public boolean getStatus()
        returns if the method: 'run' has been invoked or not, meaning if the ruleengine ran or not.
        Returns:
        the status of the rule engine

      • getRuleLogic

        public java.lang.String getRuleLogic(java.lang.String groupId)
                              throws java.lang.Exception
        returns a string representing the rule logic for the specified group the subgroup(s) will be parsed and the logic will be chained together using brackets for an easier overview.
        Parameters:
        groupId - the id of the group
        Returns:
        the rule logic in a textual form
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - exception when the logic could not be constructed

      • getRuleLogic

        public java.lang.String getRuleLogic(int index)
                              throws java.lang.Exception
        returns a string representing the rule logic for the specified group the subgroup(s) will be parsed and the logic will be chained together using brackets for an easier overview.
        Parameters:
        index - the index of the rulegroup
        Returns:
        the rule logic in a textual expression
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - exception when the logic could not be constructed

      • getReplacer

        public VariableReplacer getReplacer()
        returns the replacer object. the replacer is used to replace placeholders in the xml files with actual values.
        Returns:
        replacer object

      • setReplacer

        public void setReplacer(VariableReplacer replacer)
        sets the replacer object, which is used to replace variables specified in the xml files with real values as specified in an external properties file.
        Parameters:
        replacer - a variable replacer object

      • getObjectsLabel

        public java.lang.String getObjectsLabel()
        this label will be used - together with a running number - for all objects (that are to be tested) to identify them in the output
        Returns:
        the label used for the objects

      • setObjectsLabel

        public void setObjectsLabel(java.lang.String objectsLabel)
        set the label to a different one, if you want to modify, how the object is identified during output.
        Parameters:
        objectsLabel - the label for the objects

      • getObjectLabelNumberFormat

        public java.lang.String getObjectLabelNumberFormat()
        the objects label that is used to identify an object in output additionally has a running number. the format of this number is returned here.
        Returns:
        number format of the object label

      • setObjectLabelNumberFormat

        public void setObjectLabelNumberFormat(java.lang.String format)
        the objectlabel that is used to identify an object in output additionally has a running number. specifiy a different format here that will be used during output.
        Parameters:
        format - number format of the object label

      • getOutputType

        public int getOutputType()
        specifies if all rule results should be output (2), only for failed rules (0), only for passed rules (1). default is 0.
        Returns:
        the selected output type

      • setOutputType

        public void setOutputType(int outputType)
        sets if all rule results should be output (2), only for failed rules (0), only for passed rules (1). default is 0.
        Parameters:
        outputType - the selected output type

      • getTimestampFormat

        public java.lang.String getTimestampFormat()
        returns the format of the timestamp used for timestamp formating
        Returns:
        format of the timestamp

      • setTimestampFormat

        public void setTimestampFormat(java.lang.String timestampFormat)
        sets the format of the timestamp used for timestamp formating. follows the rules of the java.text.SimpleDateFormat class
        Parameters:
        timestampFormat - format of the timestamp
